content: The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms like Commission and Secretary. The Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado is established to conserve natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources. It includes the Rio Grande River from the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge to the New Mexico border, with boundaries extending 1/4 mile on each side. The Secretary will prepare a map and legal description of the area. The Secretary will prepare a map and legal description of the Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado, with boundaries extending 1/4 mile on each side of the river. The map and legal description of the Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado will have the same legal force as if included in the Act, with minor errors subject to correction by the Secretary. The information will be available for public inspection at Bureau of Land Management offices. Establishment of the Commission. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management and the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge manager. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and private landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will focus on Federal land, while the Commission will address non-Federal land. The Secretary will prepare a management plan for Federal land in the Natural Area, while the Commission will prepare a plan for non-Federal land. The Commission will submit their plan to the Secretary for approval. The Commission will submit the management plan for non-Federal land in the Natural Area to the Secretary for approval or disapproval. If disapproved, the Secretary will take action accordingly. The Commission must notify the Secretary of the reasons for disapproval and allow for revisions to the management plan. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The management plans should consider existing Federal, State, and local plans to create a unified preservation, restoration, and conservation plan for the Natural Area. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources while allowing for education, scientific study, and limited public recreation. The Natural Area is managed by the Secretary to conserve its natural, historic, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources. The Act does not amend the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create a Federal reserved water right, impose more restrictive Federal water quality standards, or prevent Colorado from acquiring an instream.
